skill.name: IoT UART Console (picocom)
skill.description: Use picocom to interact with IoT device UART consoles for pentesting operations including device enumeration, vulnerability discovery, bootloader manipulation, and gaining root shells. Use when the user needs to interact with embedded devices, IoT hardware, or serial consoles.

skill.author: BrownFineSecurity

security_audit.summary: This skill is a legitimate security testing tool for authorized IoT device penetration testing via UART serial connections. It uses pyserial for serial communication and logs all activity to files. No network calls, credential theft, or host code execution capabilities were detected. The skill documents common pentesting techniques but does not execute them automatically.

content.user_title: Access IoT device serial consoles for security testing
content.value_statement: IoT devices often expose UART serial consoles that provide direct access to firmware, bootloaders, and root shells. This skill enables security testers to connect to and interact with these consoles using picocom for authorized penetration testing and vulnerability research.
actual_capabilities: Connect to IoT devices via USB-to-serial adapters using picocom
Execute commands on target devices through a Python serial helper script
Detect device prompts and handle UART communication automatically
Log all serial I/O sessions for monitoring and documentation
Support for U-Boot bootloader interaction and root shell access
Batch command execution and interactive mode for flexible testing
limitations: Requires physical access to device UART pins via USB-to-serial adapter
Does not bypass hardware security or encrypted firmware
Authorized testing required - only test devices you own or have permission to assess
Skill does not perform automated exploitation - requires user guidance

use_cases.title: Firmware vulnerability research
use_cases.description: Extract and analyze firmware from IoT devices to discover security flaws and hardcoded credentials

use_cases.title: Device security assessment
use_cases.description: Conduct authorized security tests on embedded devices including privilege escalation and bootloader analysis

use_cases.title: Device root shell access
use_cases.description: Gain shell access to IoT devices for debugging, customization, or security analysis

prompt_templates.title: Basic connection
prompt_templates.prompt: Connect to my IoT device at /dev/ttyUSB0 with 115200 baud and enumerate the system

prompt_templates.title: With logging
prompt_templates.prompt: Run serial commands with logging to /tmp/device_enum.log so I can monitor the session in another terminal

prompt_templates.title: Bootloader access
prompt_templates.prompt: Connect to the device and help me interrupt the boot process to access the U-Boot bootloader console

prompt_templates.title: Batch enumeration
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a batch of enumeration commands including uname, ifconfig, ps, and check for SUID binaries

output_examples.input: Connect to the IoT device and enumerate system information

best_practices: Always use session logging to monitor serial I/O activity in real-time
Document all commands and findings for penetration testing reports
Verify you have explicit authorization before testing any device
anti_patterns: Do not test devices without proper authorization - this is illegal
Avoid making permanent modifications without backing up original configurations
Do not rely on default credentials as the only access method

faq.question: What baud rate should I use?
faq.answer: 115200 is the most common baud rate for IoT devices. Try 57600, 38400, 19200, or 9600 if output appears garbled.

faq.question: How do I monitor what Claude is doing?
faq.answer: Use the --logfile option to write all I/O to a file, then run tail -f in another terminal to watch in real-time.

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill logs all activity and does not execute commands automatically. All commands require user approval.

faq.question: What serial devices are supported?
faq.answer: The skill supports /dev/ttyUSB*, /dev/ttyACM*, and /dev/ttyS* device files for USB-to-serial adapters and built-in ports.

faq.question: Does this work with all IoT devices?
faq.answer: Only devices with accessible UART console pins. Some devices may have protected bootloaders or require physical pin connection.

faq.question: How is this different from other serial tools?
faq.answer: This skill provides a Python helper script with prompt detection, output cleaning, and session logging for reliable automation.
